PIMS 3929 SCCF FSP Integrating Climate Change Risks into Water and Flood Management by Vulnerable Mountainous Communities in the Greater Caucasus Region.

title.narrative: Integrating Climate change Risks into Water and Flood Management by Vulnerable Mountainous Communities in the Greater Caucasus

description.narrative: Project aims to reduce vulnerability of the mountain communities of the Greater Caucasus region of Azerbaijan to climate change induced water stress and flood hazards by improved water and flood management.
capital of a political entity

1) Extent to which the early warning system exists in Gabala region 2) Extent to which the Water Code responds to the climate change risks 3) Extent to which communities participate in decision making on water use issues

comment.narrative: 1) 0 (does not exist) 2) 1 (not adequately) 3) 1 (not adequately)
Gauging station is installed to provide critical data for early warning system 5 Water Users Associations are established
Gauging station is installed 5 Water Users Associations are established
Early Warning Systems are operationalized in at least 15 communities : Installation of the one hydrological station is completed Installation of the one meteorological station is completed

In 2016 FFEWS specialist finalized the concept of the CBEWS. Project held number of trainings for the communities to present CBEWS concept and trained communities. 20 community equipped with the first emergency response tool kits 1 hydrological station was installed and put in operations 1 meteo station was installed and put in operations
Installation of the monitoring system on Kura River Basin is completed: Vulnerability assessment of the mountain communities is conducted

description.narrative: To reduce the vulnerability of the communities of the Greater Caucasus GC region of Azerbaijan to water stress and hazards by improved water and flood management
Number and Type of adaptation actions implemented in national development frameworks AMAT Outcome Indicator 111

comment.narrative: 0 Normative Legal Acts NLA water code does not have IWRM relevant normative legal acts 0 NLA water code does not have relevant normative legal acts 0 NLA water code does not have relevant normative legal acts 0 NLA water code does not have relevant normative legal acts

1 NLA IWRM principles integrated in water policy 1 NLA Flood zoning regulations introduced in water code 1 NLA Conjunctive water management part of the water policy 1 NLA Public participation and gender representation rules as part of the water and flood management policy

Legal Working Group LWG was established on 25 April 2014 and from this date several meetings were held to discuss current legislation and possible changes In NLA Legal expert has prepared 12 draft proposals and 5 recommendations to Water Code Law on Environmental Protection Law On Amelioration and Irrigation Law on Ecology Safety Law on Water Supply and Wastewater Law on Water Management in Municipalities All proposal was submitted to Legal Working group and this is now under discussion During reporting period project team held 3 meetings of the LWG to conduct discussions on proposed changes to NLA Project also hired an international legal expert to bring international best practices to national legislation Report on International Legislative and Policy Best Practice in Integrated Water Resources Management as Applicable to Azerbaijan was developed and based on this report currently national and international legal experts are working on development of the new strategy to integrate and adopt IWRM and CWM principles to the NLAs List of the LWG members is attached

description.narrative: of hectares in the GC affected by improved CRM practices

comment.narrative: Zero There are no programs in place currently focused on improving climate risk management in the areas of flood and water management
Improved climate risk management affecting over 22067 sq km 2206700 ha of land in highly vulnerable region of Greater Caucasus

After replacing of CTA in 2014methodology was revised and updated work plan was prepared In accordance with the workplan the project team conducted twelve successful training sessions see page 6 on modeling and other related topics Now to reduce the vulnerability of the Greater Caucasus GC region of Azerbaijan 3 local modelers have been trained in the use of the SOBEK model hydraulic model to forecast flood events and based on the result of the model conducts risk analysis All collected data was collated and placed on the central computer server installed in the project office Currently all experts have access to the database are able to use this in the preparation of their deliverables GIS expert in cooperation with national geologist national hydrogeologist national modeler national hydrologist and lead institutional capacity expert prepared drafts of several types of maps which are evaluate and assesses risks Also project team prepared Project Atlas where they briefly show the main activities and progress During the reporting period the FFEWS specialist developed a new design and Terms of Reference for a full FFEWS in the Pilot Catchments As a part of the full system the project has developed Design of communitybased FFEWS in consultation with local communities as a pilot area in Turyanchay RB
Once funding is available and the system is installed a total of approximately 300000 hectares will benefit in the Turyanchay basin
With minor corrections proposed by the local stakeholders the concept was agreed with communities and report describing the proposed FFS implementation and operation of the FFS was developed Currently the project is working on the adaptation of this concept to the whole region
The Project has also identified and prepared a report on Requirements for Flood Forecasting Models for Project Basins Modelling Scope for a fully Integrated FFEWS The Project also prepared a detailed specification of equipment required for communitybased schemes for the 3 pilot basins The HECHMS hydrologic model was selected as being the most appropriate to use in current study Project has already conducted trainings on HECHMS provided by lead hydrologisthydraulic structure engineer and set up the HECHMS model for the Turyanchay River catchment During reporting period Water Resources EngineerIWRM Expert and National Lead Institutional Capacity Development ExpertGenderStakeholder EngagementParticipatory Specialist developed Draft institutional Integrated Water Resources Management IWRM framework and submitted it to the government officials Ministry of Emergency Situations The same time IWRM expert held three training sessions on IWRM Conceptual modelling IWRM CWM IWRM practice Climate change aspects and Conjunctive water management

description.narrative: of people who benefit from locally tailored CRM practices for flood and water risk management

comment.narrative: Zero There are no locally tailored climate change adaptation practices in place
10000000 people benefit from improved CRM practices across the GC region

Conducted studies revealed the most vulnerable communities in terms of susceptibility to waterflood risks Balakan district Mazim village Khanifa village Katekhchay village Poshtbina village Zagatala district Zaqatala city Ashgi Tala Goyam village Suvagil village Mazikh village Ititala village Ashagi Chardakhli village Uzungazmalar village Mughanli village Gakh district Gakh city Gashgachay village Gum village Almali village Zayam village Alibayli village Sheki district Sheki city Shirinbulag village Okhut village Bash Goynuk village Ashagi Goynuk village Ashagi Shabalid Selbasan village Kish village Oghuz district Filfilli village Khachmaz village Bash Dashagil village Mukhas village Bujag village Gabala district Gabala city Bum settlement Khirkhatala village Uludash village Mikhligovag village Tikanli village Hamzali village Jighatelli village Vandam village Abrikh villageGamarvan village
Once the flood forecasting and communitybased early warning system is implemented a total of approximately 211000 persons will benefit
After a wellattended Workshop on Flood Forecasting and Early Warning Systems for Local Stakeholders on 16 July 2014 the project team decide to hold meetings with communities in smaller groups community based to discuss and identify the specific needs of each group Project team held a total of 35 meetings with communities in the field and have already started to formulate CRM measure adapted to local conditions and tailored for specific communities throughout the project area Currently the project is preparing a second workshop with the communities on 5 August to evaluate all results on FFEWS and to have discussions with the communities on CWM plans Project is planning to engage around 100 participants

description.narrative: Community resilience to floods and water stress improved by introducing locally tailored climate risk management practices
Number of Local Stakeholder Committees with at least 20 women representation

comment.narrative: Zero There are no such LSCs in place

By end of Year 2 at least 3 Local MultiStakeholder Committees LSCs actively involved with regional administration in addressing climate change responses and water stress and flood damage mitigation 6 by end of year 4 and 9 by end of project all with at least 20 women membership

Again awareness building is an important component of this Local Stakeholder Committee for Turyanchay is consulted for FFEWS and will be strengthened for IWRM awareness For today project established 5 WUAs in Turyanchay RB and now work on strengthening of the knowledge and capacity through meeting and trainings for them Currently project start to establish WUA in Kishchay RB and first meetings was conducted on 2123 May with three communities To build strong relations between beneficiary and communities project involved to the meetings MoES and Regional Center specialist
The project has prepared a list of potential risk reduction and contingency measures that could be implemented locally These will be discussed with local stakeholder groups and appropriate measures to be implemented will be agreed Not all measures will be appropriate to all communities or hazards Delivery mechanisms anticipated will be via a combination of NGOs local government agencies and the communities themselvesAs a result of gender empowerment at least 3050 of the WUAs is women

description.narrative: Number of rayons to which climaterisk watershed management planning is replicated

comment.narrative: Climaterisk watershed management planning has not yet been piloted much less replicated
6 climaterisk watershed management plans in addition to the 3 pilot rayons for a total of 9

Progress expected towards the end of the project After the project will finalize following researches as evaluate available climate change information or conduct climate change assessment for areas of interest analyze climate change impacts study existing watershed management plans and existing setup in areas of interest understand water related climate risks and vulnerabilities in areas of interest participatory development of climate risk mitigation options it would be possible to develop climaterisk watershed management planning

description.narrative: Number of WUA created and or strengthened for CRM with respect to water stress and floods in project area Percentage increase in representation of women in pilot WUAs

comment.narrative: Zero Water User Associations WUA strengthened for CRM in project area Women are underrepresented in WUAs
At least 5 by end of year 2 10 by end of year 4 and 15 by end of project At least 20 women in all pilot WUAs by end of project

At the recommendation of the project MidTerm review the focus of the project activities was adjusted There was a pressing need for the adoption of adaptive management since a number of factors assumed in the original project document were either invalid or based on findings somewhat impractical The strengthening of the WUAs was particularly noted Awareness among existing WUAs is low and introducing high technology tools such as SWAT at this early stage was considered premature and unlikely to be practical The concentration for WUA strengthening will be an awareness building It will take some time to convert the existing WUAs irrigation focused to full water management activities and the awareness building will lead to this objective

description.narrative: Relevant risk information disseminated to stakeholders AMAT Outcome Indicator 211

comment.narrative: No relevant risk information is not disseminated to stakeholders
Yes relevant risk information will be disseminated to stakeholders

Project was established Working Committee on February 2014 and started discussion on possible and best solution to reach Project targets with stakeholders This Committee will work until the end of the Project
Mechanisms for dissemination have been initiated with local workshops including both community and local agency participation A subsequent process directed at specific communities is envisaged that will focus the information specifically
Information brochures have been prepared that summarise both the project in general and the proposed Communitybased Early Warning System in detail These have been distributed extensively

description.narrative: Key institutions have capacities technical skills tools and methods to apply advanced climate risk management practices for water stress and flood mitigation

National and international experts depending on their tasks assigned to them by ToRs starting to assess vulnerability of the communities and areas in their reports from October 2013 Comprehensive study will be conducted as summary of all experts contributions in mid2016

Yes An updated risk and vulnerability conducted by end of project as part of projects work to produce model flood risk maps and participatory mapping processes

National and international experts depending on their tasks assigned to them by ToRs starting to assess vulnerability of the communities and areas in their reports from October 2013 Comprehensive study will be conducted as summary of all experts contributions in mid2016

description.narrative: AMAT Output Indicator 2121 Number and Type of monitoring systems in place

comment.narrative: 0 High elevation meteorological stations 0 River Monitoring meteorological stations 0 Communitybased early warning for floods 0 Communitybased water stress early warning
6 High elevation meteorological stations 3 Highaltitude river monitoring meteorological stations 3 Community based early warning for floods 3 Communitybased water stress early warning

Lead hydrometry expert prepared detailed report of existing hydrometry network and proposals of the best available monitoring technology Expert prepared technical specification for the proof concept gauging station and project based on that announced tender to purchase first pilot gauging station Three company was attend the tender and by results of the evaluation EPTISA was declared as winner company Expected delivery of the equipment to Azerbaijan late August expected installation of Hydromet stations is early September 2015 Meteorological station will be installed in the upper mountain area of the Hamzali village 41035256 N 470503306 E hydrological station will be installed in the Savalan district 400 42766 N 47032905 E Preliminary places for the installation of the rest stations was also identify by project consultants Project consultants Lead Socioeconomic expert National Lead Institutional Capacity Development ExpertGenderStakeholder EngagementParticipatory Specialist and International FFEWS expert conduct consultations with government officials and community representatives Based on that concept and design of the FFEWS and CBFFEWS was prepared by project expert Juan Fernandez

description.narrative: Capacity Perception Index Score 1 5 to be disaggregated by gender 1 No capacity built 2 Initial Awareness raised eg workshops seminars 3 Substantial training in practical application eg vocational training 4 Knowledge effectively transferred eg passing examination certification 5 Ability to apply or disseminate knowledge demonstrated AMAT Outcome Indicator 222 Capacity Perception Index Score 1 5 to be disaggregated by gender 1 No capacity built 2 Initial Awareness raised eg workshops seminars 3 Substantial training in practical application eg vocational training 4 Knowledge effectively transferred eg passing examination certification 5 Ability to apply or disseminate knowledge demonstrated AMAT Outcome Indicator 222

comment.narrative: Baseline Score for Male and Female 1 No capacity built for climate change adaptation and risk reduction
Target Score for Male and Female 3 Substantial training in practical application eg vocational training

To study the capacity of the organizations involved to the water resource management National Lead Institutional Capacity Development ExpertGenderStakeholder EngagementParticipatory Specialist based on SWOT analysis Strengths Weaknesses Opportunities and Threats conduct survey Based on the results of those survey and meetings between project experts and officials of the involved organizations Lead Water Resources EngineerIWRM Expert with National Lead Institutional Capacity Development ExpertGenderStakeholder EngagementParticipatory Specialist develop Draft institutional framework for the implementation of IWRM in Azerbaijan The Specialists are examining the present and possible future functions of each institution to determine the most appropriate capacity building programmes and elements to define In order to build technical skills and capacity of the beneficiary and partner agencies project team conduct number of technical training sessions
Total number of persons receiving training was 125 Institutions and organizations benefitting were
SAWR NHD MoES Amelioration JSC AzerSu JSC with the majority of the participants from SAWR This training included 2 seminars that should be considered under the theme of awareness building rather than the direct technical training given in the following
1D 2D modeling
Hydata hydrologic database
Conjunctive Water Management
IWRM
HEC Geo RAS
SOBEK 2D modeling
Planning Community Based Early Warning Systems

description.narrative: Water and Flood management framework is modified to respond to adaptation needs and improve climate risk management
Development frameworks include specific budgets for adaptation actions

comment.narrative: no flood zoning policies and regulations level of action national local and community no conjunctive water management practice level of action national local and community

flood zoning regulations included in flood and river management level of action local and ocmmunity level covering 400km of the target river body conjunctive water management model developed national local and community level

The Lead Water Resources Specialist has developed the WEAP Water Evaluation and Planning model using previously collected data This has been produced for the Turyanchay basin and is now producing preliminary results on water availability and the introduction of conjunctive water management through the incorporation of the groundwater component
Engagement with IPs has been difficult from the outset of the project Reasons for this can be attributed in part to the change of Ministry from Ecology to Emergency Situations This has provoked confusion over responsibilities and obligations Only now with concrete proposals for installation of Hydromet equipment on the table has a significant degree of engagement with SAWR manifested Without a deeper level of commitment and engagement by this Agency the project will experience difficulty in securing the inclusion of adaptation measures into development frameworks This activity requires action and engagement from both project and Agency and depends to a large extent on timing of the establishment of development frameworks given that the precise role of the Agency is still under discussion It is hoped that the projects proposals for institutional development of SAWR will accelerate this discussion

description.narrative: of articles included into the Water Code supporting nonstructural climate change adaptation practices and their implementation

comment.narrative: Zero The Water Code is not sensitized to climate risks in water and flood management
At least 3 new CCA focused articles included into the water code by end of project

Draft proposals to Water Code which must support nonstructural climate change adaptation practices and integrated water resource management have been prepared and submitted to the Legal Working Group To study of the international practices on water resources management in 2014 the project hired international legalpolicy expert By the results of the work international legalpolicy expert prepared report on International Legislative and Policy Best Practice in Integrated Water Resources Management as Applicable to Azerbaijan The report is divided into five main sections Methodology Water Governance in Azerbaijan Integrating IWRM into Law IWRM Legislative and Policy Best Practices and Recommendations for Azerbaijan It is then followed by Annexes providing examples of provisions from the national legislation of select countries that reference the various best practices In order to prepare the final text of the proposal to current NLAs at the end of August 2015 it is planned to rehire international legalpolicy

description.narrative: Water Code doesdoes not mandate unified management or collaborative approaches to reduce climateinduced risk of increased flood damage and water stress

comment.narrative: Water Code is not sensitized to the importance of collaborative approaches to climate risk reduction
Amended water code mandates unified management andor collaborative approaches to reducing CC risk of increased flooding and water stress

Project lead legalpolicy specialist presented draft proposals 12 proposals and 5 recommendations to the Water Code to the LWG Next discussions will held on late August early September with participation of the international legalpolicy expert to finalize proposals

description.narrative: Financial sustainability scorecard for national system of protected areas

comment.narrative: gt35

15
Though the Project Document has been signed by the Government in June 30 2014 its implementation has been delayed to the late appointment of the Project Director and then the creation of the Project Team During the first year of implementation main activities were concentrated on the purchase of the very basic required equipment like portable water meter cars and electronic equipment for the team Therefore the financial sustainability of the project remains at the baseline level Positive changes are expected and they will be reported by the midterm evaluation

description.narrative: Total annual budget HR OPEX and CAPEX allocation for marine and coastal PAs USha

All PAs US303ha

All PAs gtUS4ha
GizilAgaj gtUS4ha

All PAs US311ha
GizilAgaj US 197ha
At first sight it looks like the total annual allocations for Marine and Coastal Protected areas has increased overall but decreased for GizilAgaj In reality however in AzN terms local currency of Azerbaijan the funding for all marine and costal areas including GizilAgaj area has increased In February 2015 AzN depreciated by 34 against the dollar Therefore if calculated using the exchange rate before AzN depreciation respective numbers for all marine protected areas would be 416ha 311x134416 and for Gizilagaj 264ha 197x134264

The decrease in the donor funding for the marine protected areas is explained by the fact that donor funding varies between years depending on the particular activities and expenses planned for that particular year In some years there is an increase and in some years some decrease in donor funding depending on particular steps This decrease is not an indicator of diminishing attention to the marine protected areas on the side of donors
In turn the small decrease in the entry fees is explained mainly by the exchange rate change between USD and the local currency The decrease is attributed mainly to the exchange rate change Current 2611 by taking into account 34 local currency devaluation would bring current fees to 3499 AzN slightly below the baseline amount of 3902 Also not forget that the number of tourists also varies between years therefore depending on many trivial reasons like weather during holiday period or something else Still the MENR pays attention to this issue and the last year made necessary changes in the regulation allowing now for visitors to buy entrance tickets directly from the National parks The MENR understands that such a low entrance fee collection is unsatisfactory and takes measures to increase the entrance fee collection by using propaganda and easing access to the sites

description.narrative: Number of MENR staff completing inservice financial training and skills development programmes

comment.narrative: gt10

0
There were no trainings or other capacitybuilding activities conducted during the first year of project implementation The project is on track and respective capacitybuilding activities are planned for the second and third years of project implementation

description.narrative: Number of business plans operational in individual marine and coastal national parks

comment.narrative:
0
Development of business plans is scheduled at later stages of project implementation The reason being that initially the protected area should be provided with currently absent basic equipment capacity building and grown ownership of the projected area As initial surveys are shown reflected in the baseline surveys no business plans are yet for the marine protected areas in Azerbaijan There is no respective expertise in Azerbaijan yet Therefore the project team is in the process of development of the respective ToR to hire an international expert to assist the MENR and the Project Team in the development of business plan There is a positive feeling based on the steps already made that the planned target will be achieved

0
The resource base of the Protected area has been significantly improved through the purchase of important equipment like portable water meter kits Even though no progress can be reported in this PIR significant advances are expected in the following years of project implementation

The Project inception workshop was held in Baku with participation of many stakeholders Also the project conducted a meeting with the local community in Baligchilar settlement during the reporting period After the meeting with the local community the idea emerged to conduct the meeting also with the schoolchildren and their teachers at the local school This meeting was also held successfully with QA session following the information session with the respective prices for the most knowledgeable students However no new partners emerged yet during first year of implementation It is expected that there will be enhanced participation in the coming years of project implementation

description.narrative: Better coordination of protection of the land border between Georgia and Azerbaijan
Better coordination of protection of the land border between Georgia and Azerbaijan
Defence - policy, planning and administration
Extent to which the capacities for border management and oversight are strengthened.

comment.narrative: Medium extent (=3).
Capacity of the State Border Service in monitoring and joint operations of the green zone on Azerbaijani-Georgian border is enhanced.
Capacities of the State Border service were enhanced through the series of study tours to European countries and 5 bilateral trainings on joint management of the borders

- Baseline assessment of training, equipment, and infrastructural needs of relevant departments is in place and used for developments of the detailed action plan - 12 training and workshop activities to enrich skills and knowledge of Border officials - 114 border guards trained - National IBM concept introduced - Bilateral agreements between two sate regulating cooperation in border management improved - Requested equipment is delivered to partners - Relevant infrastructural assistance is provided

- Baseline assessment of training, equipment, and infrastructural needs of relevant departments carried with assistance from ICMPD - 12 training and workshop activities conducted with assistance from ICMPD and FRONTEX - 114 border guards trained - National IBM concept is drafted and pending final approval by the Government - Bilateral cooperation between two sates in border management improved through development of the draft agreements on operation of border delegates that is expected to be finalized in February 2017 - Requested equipment in total amount of 271,981.09 (USD) is delivered to partners - Tenders for providing o the Relevant infrastructural assistance was posted, activities will be finalized in 2017.
Protocol on coordinated patrol of the border between AZE and GEO developed. At least one study tour conducted.

title.narrative: Capacity Building of Azerbaijan Tourism Univesity

description.narrative: Capacity Building of the Azerbaijan Tourism and Management University
The IRRF is UNDP’s results framework to monitor and report on its achievements against the Strategic Plan 2014-2017. UNDP publishes country level IRRF results that UNDP’s projects contributed to
number of new full-time equivalent jobs created for women 15+ years old
number of new full-time equivalent jobs created for men 15+ years old
total number of new full-time equivalent jobs created
number of additional females benefitting from UNDP's livelihoods interventions
number of additional males benefitting from UNDP's livelihoods interventions
number of additional people benefitting from UNDP's livelihoods interventions
The project will help the Ministry of Culture and Tourism to strengthen the institutional capacities of the Azerbaijan Tourism and Management University (ATMU).
policy, planning and administration
1) Extent to which the teaching capacities of the ATMU are enhanced to produce qualified personnel for the tourism industry 2) Extent to which regional vocational school is functional

comment.narrative: 1) Partial capacity exists (=2) 2) 0 (school does not function)

1) Strategic Development Plan for ATMU is developed and professional level of instructors improved through TOT trainings 2) Needs assessment report for the operationalization of the regional vocational school is produced.

The Project has contracted international and local experts to support ATMU in preparation of the Strategic Plan 2016-2024. The development of Strategic Plan will be completed in 2016. The Project communicated to UNWTO TedQual Head-office and received necessary documentation for the ATMU. The documents were prepared and sent back to TedQual for review.

1. Enhancing skills and competencies of academic staff of ATMU through international experience (organization of trainings). 2. Establishment of laboratories for Tourism and Hospitality Faculty of ATMU (purchase of necessary equipment). 3. Preparation of Strategic Plan 2016-2024 for ATMU. 4. Support ATMU in obtaining UNWTO TedQual Certification of the faculty of Tourism and Hospitality. 5. Organization of professional trainings for prospective personnel for tourism industry.

1. The Project hired an international consultant to conduct a training course on “Management Consultancy” for the academic staff of the ATMU on December 16-22, 2016. 17 participants (11 women and 6 men) from the Management Department, International Relations Department and Economic Department have attended the training course. 2. After the budget reduction due to the devaluation, after discussions with the Ministry of Culture and Tourism and the ATMU, it was decided to establish only one laboratory in ATMU. The activity will be implemented in 2017. 3. The Project has contracted international and local expert to support ATMU in preparation of the Strategic Plan 2016-2024. During their assignment the consultants recommended to prepare the four-year Strategic Plan instead of eight-year. The issue was discussed with the ATMU Management and it was agreed to prepare the Strategic Plan of the ATMU for 2016-2020. The Recommendations for new Strategic Plan of the ATMU were prepared and the report was handed over to the ATMU. 4. The Project communicated to UNWTO Themis Foundation regarding the UNWTO TedQual Certification of the Faculty of the Tourism and Hospitality of the ATMU and received necessary documentation for initiation of the Certification Process. The documents containing the information about current situation of the ATMU were prepared and sent back to the UNWTO Themis Foundation for review. Upon the decision of the Foundation, it was recommended to start UNWTO TedQual Pre-Audit Process. The Agreement between UNDP and UNWTO Themis Foundation was signed in December 2016. The visit of representatives of the Themis Foundation to the ATMU is planned for February 2017. 5. The Project contracted a company to organize 3 months’ trainings for perspective tourism personnel (for guides, receptionists, waiters/bartenders). Besides the specialized subjects, trainings on psychology, ethics, aesthetics, English and Russian Languages were organized. Total number of tra

1. Organization of trainings for ATMU academic staff. 2. Purchase and translation of modern tutorials. 3. Establishment of laboratory for the Faculty of the Tourism and Hospitality of the ATMU. 4. Cooperation with UNWTO Themis Foundation on UNWTO TedQual Certification of the Faculty of Tourism and Hospitality of the ATMU: • Pre-Audit Process to be conducted by the Consultant of UNWTO Themis Foundation in February 2017. • The UNWTO.TedQual Pre-audit report with the corresponding recommendations for improvement to be provided till May 2017 • Further steps for certification to be determined after the results of pre-audit process 5. Organization of the study tour of the academic and/or managerial staff to the international tourism educational institution.

description.narrative: Comprehensive labour market assessment and economic mapping conducted – yes/no Number of women benefiting from business development/support services Number of community interlocutors (municipalities, teachers, the elderly, etc) exposed to gender sensitization and principles of gender equality Number of public officials attending the trainings Number of representatives from banking and credit institutions attending the trainings.

comment.narrative: There is a shortage of information on economic opportunities and employer expectations in Masalli Low awareness about the benefits of women’s social participation among general population and local governance Public agencies and private institutions require practical skills and tools for addressing the needs of rural and female constituencies.
Project Inception workshop conducted and project staff recruited.

The Project Inceptions workshop was conducted with participation of project government counterpart, donor, representatives of international organizations, NGOs and media. Project Manager and Project Analyst were recruited.

• Assessment of the needs and concerns of rural women and the economic mapping of Masalli conducted • WRC established and operational in Masalli • 20 women attend trainings on basic professional skills • 20 women attend trainings on basics of business development and financial literacy • Total of 5 new women-led businesses are jump-started in • At least 20 women attend the training on Strengthening Women’s Social Participation in Masalli • At least 50 men and women are attend the awareness raising workshops in Masalli • Educational materials published and distributed

• Assessment of the needs and concerns of rural women and the economic mapping of Masalli conducted in June • WRC established and operational in Masalli since June, 73 registered members of active women • The trainings on basic professional skills postponed to 2017 • 27 women attended trainings on basics of business development and financial literacy • Total of 14 new women-led businesses are jump-started in Masalli • 21 women attended the training on Strengthening Women’s Social Participation in Masalli. Annual Action plan developed. • About 80 men and women attended the awareness raising workshops in Masalli • 1000 booklets – Negative Impact of Violence Against Women - were published and distributed during the events Reports and recommendations from the Assessment of needs and concern and employment opportunities were published Training materials were developed on Start and Improve your Business and Financial Literacy, NGO Establishment and Management and Strengthening Women’s Social participation themes
Women are empowered towards more active participation in economic and social life in Massalli region.
